message.div: To begin, display a spectra by selecting the menu InterSpec → Import , or more conveniently, by dragging and dropping the file of interest directly onto the graph into the corresponding box as a "Foreground," "Background," or "2nd Foreground". A foreground must be loaded before either the background or 2nd foreground will be displayed.

You can display additional spectra at the same time by dragging and dropping them in as background or 2nd foreground types. You can also import files via InterSpec → Manager and then selecting File or Saved Snapshots.

The Manager window also allows you to remove any additional spectrums by selecting the file(s) listed in the window so that it is highlighted, then selecting the Unload option on the bottom of the window.

You can also use the Manager to upload a spectrum as a "Foreground," "Secondary," or "Background" spectrum by clicking the spectrum so that it is highlighted and choosing the corresponding classification when selecting Assign As; This can also be done in the Spectrum Files tab in the bottom dock by using the drop down menus to select which spectrum(s) will display as "Foreground," "Secondary," or "Background."

This tool allows you to have fine grained control over peak parameters by either directly specifying the parameters, or by specifying which parameters should be fit for, and then re-fitting the peak. The Peak Editor also allows you to edit the nuclide associated with this peak, or change the continuum type used for the peak.
To access the Peak Editor dialog, right-click within the region of interest (ROI) of an identified peak, and then select "Peak Editor":

If you have multiple peaks next to each other sharing a ROI, the peak nearest where you right-clicked is chosen; while the Peak Editor window is open, you can change the peak it pertains to by right-clicking a new peak and selecting the Peak Editor option once again.
Check/Uncheck the "Fit" box located to the right of each box you wish to be incorporated in your spectrum.

After changing a parameter value, the change isn't propagated until either the Apply, Accept, or Refit buttons are clicked. Once one of these buttons is clicked the peak rendered on the chart, or values in the Peak Editor table will be updated with the new values.

ul.div: Clicking the Cancel button will revert the peak to the last time you clicked Apply, or if you haven't clicked Apply, it will revert the peak back to before you opened the dialog and close the dialog.
Closing the dialog via the upper right hand "×" button closes the dialog without applying any changes you may have made since the last time you clicked the apply, or refit buttons.
The Accept button applies any changes you have made, and closes the dialog.

message.div: The following are typical reasons to refer to the Peak Editor tool.

ul.li:
Fitting difficult peaks in situations where the default peak fitting algorithm is not satisfactory, or statistics are too low to yield a valid fit.
For instance, you may select for the peak centroid and/or width to not be fit for, and instead supply the value(s) you think are correct, and then refit the peak, thus gaining a more accurate peak area and/or continuum estimate.

Add a label to the peak.
For this label to also show on the chart, select the "Show User Labels" option from the View → Chart Options → Peak Labels menu.

To change the continuum type.
By default peaks are assigned Linear continuums, however changing this may yield better peak fits for regions where the continuum is more complex or a-typical.

Specifying the region of interest (ROI).
By default InterSpec guesses a ROI when fitting peaks, based on the width of the candidate peak (derived from a polynomial smoothing of the second derivative of the data), and a combination of features and statistical of the data - this may not result in the optimum selection of ROI. Specifying the ROI manually and refitting the peak can often times increase the improved estimates of the peak.

Selecting the photopeak of the nuclide responsible for creating this peak.
This dialog allows selecting the gamma-line from a list, rather than typing it in like in other locations.

When refitting a peak, not only is the current peak the Peak Editor is selected for refit, but any peaks that share its ROI are refit as well.
To prevent this, you can either force the current peak to not share a ROI by right-clicking on the peak and selecting the "Own Continuum" option, or you can use the Peak Editor to disable fitting of the various parameters for the other peaks.

Many of the fields do not have error checking beyond verifying a floating point number was entered. For instance you could specify a ROI which does not contain the peak centroid, resulting in the peak not even showing up on the chart.

There are currently (as of 20140506) a number of options you can select that are not fully supported:
selecting the continuum to be a globally defined continuum,
peak types other than Gaussian are not well supported everywhere, and we are
expecting to change the model of the peak skew from a Landau based scheme to be consistent with GADRAS
We have left these options in the GUI because we plan to better support them, and this way it will remind us to fix the issues (nobody said we were professionals!).
There can be only one Peak Editor dialog open at a time; trying to open the Peak Editor for a second peak will only change which peak the current dialog corresponds to.

The uncertainties on the parameters initially represent the errors determined from the fitting procedures, however, you should take them with a grain of salt. This is for three reasons:
These values are manually editable, so may not be what the fitting procedure determined
Fixing some parameters may result in much smaller uncertainties being derived for the other parameters, that may in fact be unreasonable.
The uncertainties are estimated from a chi squared, or likelihood, function and it has not been verified that this uncertainty is what is actually seen during use.

message.div: You can choose to view the spectrum on either a Linear or Log graph by navigating to the menu View → Chart Options; the graph is log by default.
You can add gridlines to the graph by navigating to the View toolbar, hovering over Chart Options, and selecting the Show Vertical Lines and Show Horizontal Lines.

The legend located near the top right of your graph should automatically load data corresponding to your spectrum. In the legend you will see the "Real Time" and "Live Time;" the difference between the two will give you what is otherwise known as "dead time." The legend will also provide data on the number of counts pertaining to a certain spectrum.

To make the graph constitute the entire window, select the Un-Dock Windows option also found under the View toolbar. The application provides numerous routes to access tools such that you can still access all of the tools from the Tools menu while in the un-dock mode.

To manually check notifications, select menu Help → Notifications Logs. Notification preferences can be modified by checking/unchecking the types of notifications that you desired to be disabled on the bottom right corner of the Notifications Log.
To toggle individual detectors on/off, check/uncheck the desired detector from the menu View → Detectors; all detectors are on by default.

div.div: To zoom in on a specific portion of the spectrum, click on the right-most end of the desired portion and drag your cursor to the left-most end of the desired portion; this can be done both along the x axis and y axis of the graph.

To move left/right or up/down on the spectrum while zoomed in, hold the ALT key on your keyboard, click on the graph, and drag opposite to the direction you want to move your view to; the magnitude of your drag will determine how far you move on the graph, so release accordingly.
To zoom back out to the full graph, click and drag left; the extent of the drag dictates the final magnification.

Double-click anywhere on the graph above the energy level you wish to identify a peak. Double-clicking again near an existing peak will prompt the application to fit for another peak if it finds another nuclide appropriate and energetically close in vicinity.

Hold CTRL and left-click drag over the ROI; be sure to select the appropriate number of peaks you want to prompt the application into identifying - it will not identify any if the selected quantity is unavailable.
Dock the windows and select "Search for Peaks" on the bottom left of the window. Note that this method will identify all possible peaks on the entire spectrum.

Dock the windows and select "Add" on the bottom left of the window. Change the parameters under the Peak Manager tab to adjust the peak by double-clicking on each parameter and typing in the desired quantity.
Hold SHIFT and left-click drag over the ROI to erase the identified peak(s).
Right-click on a highlighted peak and select the "Peak Editor". In the Peak Editor dialog, select "Delete" from the bottom right of the window.
Dock the windows, select "Clear all Peaks" on the bottom left of the window, and select "Yes" in the small window that pops up. Note that this method will delete all identified peaks.
Right-click the identified peak and select "Delete Peak" in the dialog that pops up.

message.div: One way to recalibrate is by navigating to the Peak Manager tab on the bottom dock of your window, selecting ID Nuclides so that the application can identify what it deems to be appropriate nuclides for your given spectrum, navigating to the Energy Calibration tab also on the bottom dock, and then checking/unchecking under "Calib. Peak" the nuclides the application identified that you are in agreement with; checked boxes classify the identity of the nuclide as "true," unchecked boxes classify the identity as "false."

div.ul: You can still manually change the calibration parameters by adjusting the "Offset Term," "Linear Term," and "Quad. Term" located on the left half of the dock under the Calibration tab.

message.div:
InterSpec may attempt to automatically guess the detector response function for newly loaded spectra if you have set the appropriate directories (described bellow) and a detector response function (DRF) with either a name matching the model of detector is found, or a generic detector with a similar efficiency to manufacturer published specifications is found.
If an appropriate DRF is not found, or an incorrectone is guessed, you can change the detector via menu Tools → Detector Edit/Select, or by clicking on the camera icon (
) found in the following locations:
Tools → Activity/ Shielding Fit menu
Tools → Gamma XS Calc menu
Tools → Reference Photopeaks menu (if undocked) or 3rd tab Reference Photopeaks (if docked)
Changing the DRF in any of the above locations is equivalent.

The primary component of the detector response function is the
intrinsic efficiency
of the detector as a function of energy; the detector response can also optionally contain the Full Width at Half Maximum (FWHM) for peaks as a function of energy. Some of the peak fitting routines loosely consult the FWHM of the detector response, if its available, for the initial value of peak width when fitting a new peak; the fit for the peak is in no way constrained by the FWHM of the detector response. If the detector response does not contain FWHM information, initial values of the peak width for the fit are derived from the data, and are almost always sufficiently close to the true width to allow the fit to converge.

The Detector Edit/Select will provide some generic detector response functions (DRFs) as well as an oppritunity to use DRFs from GADRAS, SimpleMass, free from equations, standard equation coefficients, or absolute efficiencies specified using a comma seperated value (CSV) or tab seperated value (TSV) file. The DRFs are used when fitting for shieldings and source activity, and displaying refernce photopeak amplitudes..
User defined detectors (either via upload or manual equation entry) can currently only contain efficiency information.

Selecting Response Functions Once a detector is selected from the below described source options, the various indicators such as the reference gamma lines should reflect the change efficiencies. However, if the detector select dialog is closed, or the Cancel button clicked, InterSpec will revert back to using your previously selected detector. You must click the Accept button to continue using your newly selected detector.
GADRAS:
InterSpec can use the same format DRF as used by GADRAS-DRF as long GADRAS-DRF has previously used with the DRF in order to create the Efficiency.csv file to go along with Detector.dat. Using GADRAS-DRF detector response functions has the advantage of including both intrinsic efficiency and FWHM information (which may help peak fitting). For further information on GADRAS-DRF detector response functions see: GADRAS-DRF 18.5 User’s Manual. In order to use GADRAS-DRF response functions you must point the GADRAS tab of the Detector Edit/Select to the root directory of your GADRAS-DRF detectors. This root directory will be saved as a user preference across sessions.
The discrete energy/efficiency pairs in the Efficiency.csv file are interpolated between using Akima interpolation. The Detector.dat file that defines the detector in GADRAS-DRF, is used to determine the FWHM information. Specifically parameter 6, 7, and 8 (denoted by P6, P7, and P8 respectively) are used according the following pseudo-code:
def getFWHM( energy ): //P6---> resolution @ E=0 (keV) //P7---> % FWHM @ 661 keV //P8---> resolution power if energy ≥ 661 or P6=0 return 6.61×P7×(energy/661)P8 if P6 < 0.0 var p = P81.0/log(1.0-P6) return 6.61×P7×(energy/661)p
if P6 > 6.61×P7 return P6;
var p = sqrt((6.61×P7)2-P62)/6.61; return sqrt(P62+(6.61×p×(energy/661)P8)2)
Rel. Eff:
The "Rel. Eff." detector response functions are specified using CSV or TSV files that provide detector dimensions and relative efficiencies at a given distance. A single CSV or TSV file may contain multiple lines with each line specifying a DRF. The format of the file is:
Lines starting with the string "#credit:" will be displayed to the user to provide context/credit/information about the DRFs contained in the file. XHTML may be used in the descriptions. Lines otherwise starting with a "#" character will be ignored.
The relative efficiency is specified using an equation of the form:
exp( c0 + c1*x1 + c2*x2 + c3*x3 + c4*x4 + c5*x5 + c6*x6 + c7*x7)
Where x is the energy in MeV, and c0, c1, etc are specified in the CSV or TSV file.
Multiple files containing DRFs may be specified, and will remembered across user sessions.
The columns in the CSV/TSV are:
1: Display Name 2: Eff rel. to 3x3 NaI 3: Name 4: c0 5: c1 6: c2 7: c3 8: c4 9: c5 10: c6 11: c7 12: p0 (unused) 13: p1 (unused) 14: p2 (unused) 15: Calib Distance (cm) 16: Radius (cm)
Upload:
You can upload a a CSV file that lists the intrinsic efficiency at multiple energies in order to create a detector response function in InterSpec . The first column of the CSV file should be the energy in keV, and the second column should be the percent efficiency (a decimal number between 0 and 100) for a gamma at that energy striking the detector face to be detected within the photopeak centered at that energy. Subsequent columns on each line are ignored. Lines in the file characterized by first non-whitespace character other than a digit are skipped. The file may also be delimited by commas, spaces or tabs; multiple contiguous delimiters are treated as a single delimiter.
An acceptable input file may look like:
Energy (keV), Efficiency (%)
10, 0.0
20,10.3
25 28.3
30,43.6
35 54.0
...
The Efficiency.csv file produced by "GADRAS" inside a detector files folder is an acceptable input.
After uploading the efficiency file, you will be prompted to either enter the detector diameter, or upload a Detector.dat file from "GADRAS" so that the geometrical efficiency can be calculated. If a Detector.dat is uploaded, the detectors peak width response will also be known to InterSpec as well.
The detectors' name will automatically be assigned to be the same as the efficiency CSV file (minus the extension) used to create the detector.
When evaluating efficiencies for energies between the provided values, Akima Interpolation is used. This interpolation method was chosen as it is continually differentiable, only uses data from next neighbor points to determine value, and does not suffer from the same overshoots or oscillations that polynomial splines (e.g. third order splines) suffer from.
A comparison of Akima, Cubic Spline, and linear interpolation methods for a set of intrinsic efficiency pairs provided by "GADRAS" for a hand-held detector.
Note: we have to improve this chart!
Formula:
If either the intrinsic or absolute efficiency is known as a mathematical function of energy (represented by "×" in the input function), it may be entered here; the detector diameter must also be known. The formula entered may use energy in either keV or MeV as long as the appropriate check box is selected. The evaluated formula should yield a number between 0 and 1 for the energy range it is valid in. The input formula must be a function of a single variable (energy) represented as a "×" in the formula.
Intrinsic efficiency formulas represent the fraction of gammas which strike the detector face, that will end up in the full energy photopeak of the gammas incident energy.
Absolute efficiency formulas represent the fraction of gammas that leave the source, which will be recorded in their full energy photopeak, at a specified distance; hence when this efficiency is selected you will also have to enter a distance the input formula corresponds to.
Valid Equations: Equations that can be entered follow standard mathematical rules, and can make use of the following functions:
abs, sqrt, sin, cos, tan, asin, acos, atan, atan2, sinh, cosh, tanh, exp, log, ln (synonym for log) , log10
and functions that take two arguments : min, max, pow
The following arithmetic operators may be used: +, - , /, *, ^, **
The following logical operators may be used: ==, !=, >, >=, <, <=, &&, ||
Logical operations result in a value of 0.0 if false, and 1.0 if true, and may be chained together, ex.
0.5*(x<50||x>100) + 0.75*(x>=50&&x<=100) will result in a function with value of 0.75 between 50 and 100, and 0.5 everywhere else.
An example input formula could be:
exp(-343.63 + 269.10*log(x) -83.80*ln(x)^2 + 13.00*pow(log(x),3) -1.01*log(x)^4)
After a formula is entered you may click the Set button to display the function on the chart to ensure the function is reasonable; the y-axis of this chart will always be set to display form 0 to 1. Any syntax errors encountered during parsing of the formula will be reported in the Information and Warnings widget, with some diagnostics.
Recent:
This is a list of recently used detector response functions you can choose to use again - currently this list just lists all used detector - in the future it is planned to only hold detectors defined from uploaded, manually entered formula, or created from test data (a planned feature).
It is a good idea to uniquely name your uploaded or formula defined detector response functions for later identification.
Select Tools → Activity Shielding Fit to launch the tool.
In the leftmost box in the tool window, check/uncheck under the "Use" column the peaks you wish to use in determining the activity of the shielding; checked boxes indicate a "false" peak.
Check/uncheck the box next to "Multiple nuclides contribute to peak" located at the bottom left corner of the window to account for cases when two nuclides may be the cause of the same gamma peak.
When peaks from your background spectrum may interfere with your foreground spectrum, check/uncheck the box next to "Subtract Background Peaks" located at the bottom left corner of the window.

To account for more shielding, including advanced cases of shielding, select the Material icon located at the top right of the window to add a shielding source, and select the appropriate material/thickness accordingly. For a material that is not provided under the Material option select the Generic icon, input the "Areal Dens.[ity]" and atomic number.

div.ul: If accounting for shielding here, be sure to check/uncheck the "Fit" box located to the right of each Material or Generic box you wish to be incorporated in your spectrum. This ability allows you to immediately see the effects of a small variance in the shielding source such that you can better determine the accurate choice of shielding material.

message.div:
You can also "Import Source Shielding XML Model" by hovering the cursor over the settings icon (
)in the top right of the window, and selecting "Upload Model."

No matter what method of inputting shielding is used, be sure to input the distance the measurement was taken from the shielding source in the box next to "Distance" on the top right of the window; it is by default set to 100 centimeters.

div.ul: The application has the ability to identify and adjust the units you input after the numerical figures; you will not need to normalize the units you plan to input.

message.div: This tool allows you to obtain information about aged nuclides, such as activities or gamma/alpha/beta production rates, or the decay chain as well as further information about each of the daughter nuclides. There are two main portions of this tool used to extract information: the Activity Chart tab and Decay Chain tabs; usage information and hints are offered in the similarly named subsections.

For both of these tools the initially selected nuclide information will be displayed for whatever nuclide the Reference Photopeaks tool is currently displaying, or if it is not displaying any reference gamma lines for nuclides, a default nuclide.
The Activity Chart display can display the activity, or emission rate of gamma, beta, or alpha particles as a function of time for the chosen parent and daughter nuclides.
Clicking on the chart will bring up a text listing of nuclide activities and decay particle types, their energies and intensities, as well as some additional information, all for the time clicked.

If the check-boxes in the legend are un-checked, then the nuclide listed next to it will not be displayed on the decay chart; this is useful when the activities of a number of daughter products overlap (hence hiding each other) and you wish to verify the location of the decay curve.
Adjusting the Time Span changes the x-axis range displayed, and can be useful for zooming in on the initial decay period.

Changing Nuclide The selected nuclide can be changed by double-clicking the icon representing the nuclide in the upper bar listing the nuclides; in the example screen shot below it looks like:
. Alternatively you could remove the isotope by clicking the
symbol in the nuclides icon, and then add a new nuclide by clicking the icon. You can add multiple isotopes so you can view their decay information together.

div.div: Note: The "nuc. search" field will update the element and isotope selection fields with suggestions as you type. No suggestions will be offered before you enter text, but the element and isotope fields will still be populated if you wish to select your nuclide that way. If you wish to get quantitative information on the activity as a function of time, you can select the initial activity of the nuclide. If you wish to have a minimum age for the decay chart to start at, you can also fill in a minimum age here.

Example screen shot of the Nuclide Decay Information tool showing the Decay Chain tab.
Note: You can click on a nuclide to obtain further information about its half life, parents, and decays.
Double-click on a nuclide to get information about the decay products (gamma/beta/alpha) from that nuclide. If you have selected multiple nuclides in the upper source area, the decay chain can only be shown for one at a time. Clicking on the icon for a different nuclide (in the example shown above, Pu239 instead of U235) will display the decay chain for that parent nuclide.

message.div: This tool allows you to determine the cross section for gammas of arbitrary energy through any material in InterSpec's library, or any element or material formula you enter. If the density of the material is known or specified, as well as the length of traversal through the material, the fraction of gamma rays that will make it through the material without interacting with it is also given as the "Trans. Frac.". Further, if a detector is specified, along with the distance from the source to the detector (note this is from the source, and not from the shielding around it), then efficiency estimates for detection of the gamma rays inside the full energy peak will also be given.
Some things to note about each of the fields are:

ul.li: Energy: Values entered must be in keV and inside the range of 10 to 10000 keV.

Material/mass-formula: Here you can enter any material or element in the InterSpec database (e.x. Polyethylene, Air, Fe, etc.) and you will be assisted with a suggestion popup as you type to let you know what is in the database. If you choose to enter a mass-formula instead, you should enter the chemical symbol (e.x. C, Ni, Fe, etc.) followed by the mass fraction of that element in the material (so a number between 0 and 1), where the sum of mass fractions should add up to 1.0; if they dont add up to 1.0, then a scale will be applied internally so that the relative proportions remain the same, but the total mass fraction will be 1.0. Examples of mass-formulas include 'C0.5H0.2Ni0.4', 'Fe0.5U0.5', 'Al0.25Be0.35H0.4'.

Total att. cross section: This is the sum of the Compton, Photoelectric and Pair Production cross sections; Rayleigh scattering is not included in this number since it does not effect the gammas energy. To get the mean free path of the gamma through the material in cm, you can divide this number by the density (in units of g/cm3). To get the probability of a gamma passing through the material without interacting with it you can multiple this number by density and thickness of the shielding then take the exponent of the negative of this number, e.g. prob = exp(-xs × density × thickness), which is what the "Trans. Frac" field provides.
Density: this must be specified in order for the "Trans. Frac." field to be calculated for you, and must be in units of g/cm3
Length: This is the thickness of the attenuating material, and can be entered in any distance units InterSpec accepts, as long as they are specified.

Trans. Frac.: The fraction of gammas that will make it through the attenuating material at the specified energy, density and thickness, without interacting or down scattering in energy. Note that this is not the total fraction of the incomming gammas which will exit the shielding, as some gammas will scatter to lower energies and still make it through the shielding, but not into the detected full energy peak.

Detector: This is optional and will be set to the same detector as the spectrum you are currently working on if it has a detector associated with it; otherwise you can click on the icon and select a detector to use for the calculation. If a detector is selected, you will be able to input a distance from the source to the detector to also get the geometrical and detector efficiency calculation as well.

Distance: This field will only be visible if a detector is selected. This is the distance from the source to the detector. Note, this is not the distance from the shielding to the detector, but from the center of the actual source to the detector face.

Detection Efficiency: This is the combination of the geometrical efficiency (the probability of a gamma from the source hitting the face of the detector), and the intrinsic efficincy of the detector (the probability that if a gamma hits the detector face, it will be detected in the full energy peak). Note that this field does not include the effects of attenuation.

message.div: Access and launch the Reference Photopeaks tool by selecting Tools → Reference Photopeaks menu (undocked) or 3rd tab.
Inputting the "Nuclide" and "Age" will immediately alter the calibration of the spectrum.

If the calibration is still not accurate, you can manually account for potential shielding by selecting the shielding material from the list of options, and inputting the appropriate thickness. Often this will alter your spectrum such that peaks will fit the isotope they reflect more accurately.

div.ul: Input the units in which the thickness of the material was measured after inputting the quantity. Separate the units from the number with a single space; trouble fitting will not occur otherwise.

div.div: Content to eventually be placed here
Content to eventually be placed here

message.div: The Math/Command Terminal is a command line tool for InterSpec. It can be used to compute simple to very complicated math expressions, accomplish text-based interactions with the spectra, and reference data from the user’s current activity.
The tool can be accessed by selecting the Math/Command Terminal selection from the Tools toolbar in un-docked mode, or selecting its corresponding tab in the bottom dock of the window.

The Math/Command Terminal tool features the ability to compute complex calculations on the fly with a simple, common syntax. Powered by MuParserX, the tool comes built-in with various pre-defined operators and functions, and are listed in the following. Function calls along with combinations with different operators can be evaluated directly into the Terminal and outputted on the history of text. The syntax for executing functions and operations are listed as so:

pre.code:
Binary Operator: [operand 1] (operator) [operand 2]
Ternary Operator: [operand 1] (operator 1) [operand 2] (operator 2) [operand 3]
Functions: function_name( [arg 1], [arg 2], [arg 3], ... )

message.div: The following are functions and operators currently supported by the Math/Command Terminal:

tr.td: e to the power of x. (Takes 1 argument)
If x is true, y, else, z

div.div: The Math/Command Terminal also stores constants that are available to use inside arguments of functions as well as operations. The following are currently stored constants inside the tool:

tr.td: Natural log base *obtained from M_E in C++
Square root of 2 *obtained from M_SQRT2 in C++

message.div: The Math/Command Terminal also features the ability to reference values from displayed data as well as accomplish certain interactions with spectra and the environment. Dynamic functions are able to be combined with math expressions for a powerful combination of accurate calculations without the need to physically view and copy the data. Static functions allow the user to interact with the displayed spectrum and environment and do certain tasks such as adding peaks, deleting peaks, and changing the environment appearance. Static functions have no real return value and therefore are NOT allowed to be combined inside expressions. The Terminal will return an error message if static functions are combined within expressions. The syntax for calling these functions are similar to how math functions are called:

div.i: *note that there must not be any spaces between the function name and the parentheses for arguments! The Terminal will interpret this as an error.

pre.code:
Static functions: static_function( [arg 1], [arg 2], [arg 3], ... )
Dynamic functions: dynamic_function( [arg 1], [arg 2], [arg 3], ... )
[operand 1] (operator 1) dynamic_function( [arg 1], [arg 2], [arg 3], ... )

message.div: Different functions may have a certain number of required arguments inside the parenthesis. These arguments are separated by commas, and can be represented as constants, identification values, numeric values, and string values. Certain functions may require a set of these arguments in a FIXED order, or else an error is returned. Some arguments are OPTIONAL, and are highlighted in YELLOW ITALICS. The following are InterSpec functions that are currently available inside the Math/Command Terminal:

tr.td: Output information about defined variables. Can specify a single variable, if given as an argument, or output all variable values if no argument is specified.
Deletes a stored variable. If the variable does not exist, then a proper error message is returned.
Sets the displayed x-axis range of the current spectrum. Automatically detects the lower-x and upper-x bounds. Outputs if action was a success or not.
Searches for and adds peak onto the spectrum at the specified energy value.
Searches for and deletes peak at the specified energy value in the spectrum.
Searches for and refits peak at the specified energy value in the spectrum.
Sets the nuclide and age inside the ‘Reference Photopeaks Tab’. If the age is not specified, then the default age is provided. If the nuclide could not be found, then nothing happens.
Darkens the text areas for the Terminal and whitens the text font.

td.i: *Any argument passed in will not affect the function.

tr.td: Whitens the text areas for the Terminal and darkens the font. Currently set to default.

td.i: *Any argument passed in will not affect the function.

tr.td: Gets the nuclide’s intensity value at a specified energy. Returns error message if no energy value could be matched with user’s specification or no nuclide is shown.
Gets nuclide’s intensity value at specified energy and particle. Returns error message if both of these parameters could not be matched.
Returns the live time (in seconds) of spectra, or 0 if not known.
Returns the real time (in seconds) of spectra, or 0 if not known.
Automatically detects single spectra and returns its live time value. Returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Automatically detects single spectra and returns its real time value. Returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Returns a peak’s area at a specified x-value. Returns 0 if no peak found.
Returns a peak’s mean at a specified x-value. Returns 0 if no peak found.
Returns a peak’s sigma at a specified x-value. Returns 0 if no peak found.

td.i: *Peak must be gaussian or else error is returned.

tr.td: Returns a peak’s full width at half-maximum at a specified x-value. Returns 0 if no peak found.
Returns a peak’s amplitude at a specified x-value. Returns 0 if no peak found.
Returns a peak’s chi-squared degrees of freedom at a specified x-value. Returns 0 if no peak found.
peakGauss( energy: value, x0: value, x1: value )
Returns a peak’s gaussian at a specified x-value and bounds. Returns 0 if no peak found or x-boundaries are equivalent.
Returns the p-value from a specific chi-score and degrees of freedom.
Returns minimum number of channels of channel energies or gamma counts for spectrum. Returns 0 if neither is defined.
Returns gamma channel containing energy. If energy is below zero, then 0 is returned. If the energy is above the last channel, the last channel is returned.
Returns gamma channel contents for a specified spectrum in a specified channel. Returns 0 if channel energies is not defined or channel is invalid (too large).
Returns lower energy of specified gamma channel for a specified spectrum.
Returns central energy of specified gamma channel for a specified spectrum. For last channel, returns width of second-to-last channel.
Returns energy for a spectra just past energy range the specified channel contains. Returns error if channel is invalid.
Returns energy with of a channel. If at last channel, then width of second-to-last channel is returned.
gammaIntegralFor( spectra: id/string, energy_low: value, energy_high: value )
Get integral of gamma counts between energy_low and energy_high for a spectrum. Returns 0 if channel energies or gamma counts invalid.
gammaSumFor( spectra: id/string, start_bin: value, end_bin: value )

Get the sum of gamma channel contents for all channels in between (inclusive) start_bin and end_bin for a spectrum. Returns 0 if start_bin too large or gamma counts invalid. If end_bin too large, then it will be clamped to number of channels.
Same as numGammasFor( spectra: id ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaChannelFor( spectra: id, energy: value ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaContentFor( spectra: id, energy: value ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaLowerFor( spectra: id, channel: value ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaCenterFor( spectra: id, channel: value ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaUpperFor( spectra: id, channel: value ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaWidthFor( spectra: id, channel: value ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaIntegralFor( spectra: id, energy_low: value, energy_high: value ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaSumFor( spectra: id, start_bin: value, end_bin: value ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaMinFor( spectra: id ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.
Same as gammaMaxFor( spectra: id ). Automatically detects displayed spectrum, returns error message if multiple or no spectra detected.

message.div: The Math/Command Terminal for InterSpec also features the ability to use string constants that are used for arguments inside several InterSpec functions. These constants can be used directly as its ID’s instead of placing them inside quotes as strings (eg. “hello” or “hello world!”).

tr.td: Used for live time and real time functions, as well as numerous gamma functions.
Used for live time and real time functions, as well as numerous gamma functions.
Used for live time and real time functions, as well as numerous gamma functions.

message.div: The Math/Command Terminal is a command line tool for InterSpec. It can be used to compute simple to very complicated math expressions, accomplish text-based interactions with the spectra, and reference data from the user’s current activity.
The tool can be accessed by selecting the Math/Command Terminal selection from the Tools toolbar in un-docked mode, or selecting its corresponding tab in the bottom dock of the window.
The Nuclide Search tool can be accessed either from the bottom dock of the window, or from the Tools toolbar when in the un-docked mode.
This tool allows the user to search for nuclides with specific constraints on energy, branching ratio (BR), and half life (HL).

div.div: This tool allows you to use two dose measurements taken at different distances from a source to determine the absolute distance to the source from the nearer measurement. This is useful when the source is behind a wall or in a large container and the position of the source can not be determined otherwise.

For the "Near", "Far", and "Background" intensity values you can use an units of dose or intensity you want (e.x. rem, millirem, sievert/hour, gamma counts per second, etc.), but it must be the same for each field. Similarly, you can use any unit of distance (ex. meters, feet, attoparsecs, etc.) for the distance between the measurements, as the answer will be provided in these same units.

Entering a background intensity is optional, but for the case of low intensity sources, it will help to provide a more accurate answer by subtracting this value from both the near and far measurements.

This tool assumes the source intensity falls off as 1/r2 which is generally the case, however there can be circumstances where scattering or other effects will cause this to not be true; also, over huge distances attenuation in the air will cause this assumption to be invalid as well. You can use the Gamma XS Calc tool to calculate the expected attenuations for different energies through air to see if it is significant effect. (TODO: insert some example effects at different distances here)

The formula used to calculate the distance in front of the near measurement is shown bellow in pseudo-code format, and already assumes the background has been subtracted from FarIntensity and the NearIntensity.
let a = FarIntensity - NearIntensity let b = 2×FarIntensity×DistanceBetween let c = FarIntensity×DistanceBetween×DistanceBetween let DistanceInFrontOfNear = (-b-sqrt(b²-4×a×c))/2a

message.div: Select Tools → File Parameters to launch the tool.
Select which spectrum ("Foreground," "Secondary," "Background") you wish to view/input parameters for in the top left of the window that pops up.
Enter the "Allow Edit" mode to input parameters the input file lacked, and/or edit the parameters the input file was incorrect about.

div.ul: If ever the application is unable to run activity calculation, visit this tool; InterSpec will need all parameters, especially in cases when the input file did not provide them.

The changes made will not be propagated to the rest of the application until the
icon is pressed.

message.div: The Energy Range Count tool will sum the number of gammas in a selected energy range. To select an energy range, manually input , click the up/down arrows in each box to toggle to the desired number, or hold both the SHIFT and ALT keys on your keyboard while simultaneously dragging the desired region for energy count.

In order to save the alterations you made to a spectrum file that occurred during calibration, navigate to the Interspec → Save As; this will save the entire InterSpec state (includes current spectra) to the database under your specified name/description which you can restore back to at a later time. To save any changes in the future, select InterSpec → Save which will overwrite the save data. This is known as the HEAD, and will always contain the latest changes.
To save a bookmark (also known as tag) of the current state, select InterSpec → Tag. Tags can not be overwritten. Think of them as an archived state.
To open either the entire application state or individual spectra, navigate to Interspec → Load or Interspec → Manager → Saved Snapshots.
To change whether InterSpec will automatically save application state, nagivate to Help → Options → Automatically save snapshots.

To prepare your new spectrum(s) in a format appropriate to send to customers, navigate to the InterSpec → Manager menu, then select the spectrum(s) you wish to download, and, once your files of choice are highlighted, select Download (as TXT, CSV, or XML/N42 File format) in the bottom of the tab.

div.ul: The Manager has the ability to combine numerous files.

message.div: To graphically recalibrate a spectrum, right-click on the original energy and drag to the desired modified energy. Once complete, a small window will pop up prompting you to accept the calibration changes you are attempting to incur; on this window you can manually adjust the energy quantities either by 1) directly entering the values into the appropriate boxes, or 2) ticking the arrows for a 1keV perturbation at the upper energy range of the spectrum; once it has been calibrated sufficiently select Accept on the bottom of the pop up window.

div.ul: If you have multiple calibrations, check/uncheck the previous calibrations you would like to keep in effect at the bottom of the pop-up window(s).
